author: davbar
title: My visit to hospital to have a pacemaker fitted.
body:
I was taken to Doncaster Hospital by ambulance the beginning of March, having been suffering from a very low pulse and breathlessness for some months. On arrival at the ICU I was met with the most professional staff and having never been in hospital I felt extremely vulnerable. The staff were very supportive and able to give me information from the ECG which showed that I had a heart block and that I would be admitted into the Cardiology Ward where I would probably have a Pacemaker fitted.  
I was admitted to Cardiology that day where I was attached to a heart machine and my pulse and blood pressure were monitored regularly. Staff were concerned regarding my pulse which was between 28 and 30 bpm. During the night it fell below this and one of the doctors came to me, about my condition as he was extremely concerned.  
I had a Pacemaker fitted and almost immediately. I felt better as my pulse returned to normal. I am now on the road to recovery. I dread to think what could have happened if I had not gone into hospital that day. I cannot thank the staff at the hospital enough and I have already sent thank you cards to the two depts.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: HelenL
title: LiveWell - Working Win.  My access to this service.
body:
At a time when I was having to take some time out due to being overwhelmed and overcome at work it was suggested to me that I refer myself into the Working Win project (hosted by South Yorkshire Housing Association). At a time when I knew that mental health services were at their limits due to the levels of demand, I grabbed at the opportunity to speak to someone.  
I gained a Return to Work Coach and a Health and Wellbeing Coach along with access to Westfield Health and TogetherAll (an online chat portal for support). I can honestly say that I have had the best, most wrap around care, most bespoke support and have been made to feel so valued and 'heard' than I have ever with any other service.  
My Return to Work Coach understood my role and level I had reached in my organisation and understood the pressures and anxieties that I was experiencing. He coached me through organising my thoughts about my role, what it was that had got me to this point and therefore what was going to get me back to work but in a better more sustainable way. We created a plan of action which I used to help prompt me in my first return to work chat with my organisation. We also talked about progression, about what I actually wanted to do workwise, why shouldn't I look for something more in tune with my likes and dislikes rather than just where my talents lie. These two things 'my skills' and 'my preferences' were not necessarily in the same role. He also shared with me his experiences which led me to trust him further.  
My Wellbeing Coach was just the person I needed. We only spoke a small number of times but I was able and comfortable to share everything. Whilst she made me feel comfortable in the beginning she also also pushed me to test and question some of my thoughts and assumptions. To question why I thought the way I did about certain things. To realise that just because one person has an opinion on you or your work that might be negative, that should cloud or rule out any other positive voices. Why listen to that 1%? Why try to please that 1% when they are never going to be pleased at anything?  
We also talked about perceptions of working women, those with high positions in organisations and who had leadership positions. What their reputation might be like and what they thought about it. The fact that my perception of having that high position was that it would mean loosing the work/life balance I would want by working 50 hours per week, made me not want to pursue anything like that. She challenged that perspective and offered up examples of where a job share arrangement for two women in a Director role had succeeded.  
Both my coaches were a directory of information and further help that is available, something that I would have struggled to find myself. Whether it was clips of speakers knowledgeable about the topic we had just been speaking about or resources on interview techniques and question styles.  
The existence of this project has been a lifeline to me. The people I have met through it have been amazing, caring, knowledgeable, friendly, constructive, practical, thought provoking and committed. I will forever be grateful to them as I feel that I have grown and changed as a person because of their input. I believe that this type of service should be available to anyone and directly through healthcare providers and if in my professional career I had the power to make that happen, I would.  
I will be forever grateful and thankful.

title: poor administration
body: Poor administration, on DR. iQ Dr had prescribed medicine to my son but the prescription was not sent to pharmacy, i have been to surgery and also telephone calls for five working ways, no one helped, my son had a lot of pain in the right ear.

author: Whoever
title: Lack of information about the approach of the 'CFS' clinic
body:
I have had Myalgic Encephalomyelitis for the last forty years plus. I need a specialist's letter confirming the diagnosis, a written management / treatment plan, and an OT to arrange a wheelchair assessment.  
My GP would like the treatment plan to advise on prescribing LDN, mestinon or other medication to see if it will halt the decline - I can't currently get up for more than about ten minutes a time a few times a day.  
The GP referred me to the above clinic. When I rang the clinic to ask if they could confirm that their clinical approach is to regard ME, in line with the WHO and the NHS, as a physical/neurological disease, and not as psychosomatic or an FND - as this information was not on the web page - they couldn't tell me, and didn't even understand the question.  
I do not consent to being seen or treated by, (or referred to) doctors or other health care professionals who do not regard ME/CFS as a physical/neurological disease. This is to ensure I have up-to-date doctors who will not harm me by prescribing GET or other discredited 'treatments', it provides me with continuity in my health care, and it means I don't come away feeling 'gaslighted' by doctors telling me my disability is 'all in the mind' when the science (for example at Stanford University among other international centres) has research data showing clearly that it isn't.  
I do not want to receive treatment based on a thoroughly discredited piece of research done in the UK called 'Pace', which was so badly done, it is used as a teaching example of how not to do research. Because of the lack of information on the web page of the 'CFS' clinic, and the lack of awareness of the issue by the person who answered the phone I have had to decline the referral as I simply have no assurance of the approach they are using or that they will respect the boundaries of my consent and be able to find anyone suitable to see me.  
When I explained the boundaries of my consent to the admin, the response was there is nowhere in the system to record this so the information cannot even be passed on ahead of the appointment.  
I have spoken with my solicitor and as there seems to be no way to get the information ahead of the appointment or for my consent to be recorded, I have decided to refuse to be seen there.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Excellent practice
body: I along with my family have been patients at the surgery for almost 20 years. I have nothing but praise for the treatment we have received during this time. The reception staff do their best to help but have their limitations with balancing the no of appointments available with demand. The GP's in my experience are very professional, reassuring and are thoroughly trained in dealing with most issues and are happy to refer to specialists when needed. I have a daughter with very complex needs and am very pleased of how her needs are accommodated compassionately by the surgery. Overall I believe this is a wonderful caring practise and we are very fortunate to have such great dedicated professionals treating us especially in these difficult times.

title: Excellent prompt referrals and diagnosis
body: I visited AEC and received excellent service the same day followed by referrals. I had Ct, X-ray and bloods the same day, US 2 days later and gynaecology within 2 weeks. All was well. Excellent caring and efficient staff in all departments. I can not fault anything. I could not have got a better service even if I had paid. Well done all.

author: Robfaethevalley
title: Professional staff for my endoscopy
body:
In for an investigation endoscopy and gastroscopy today.  
Thank god for the NHS. The staff are so professional & make you feel calm during the visit. They deserve any benefits coming their way after the year we have had.  
Exceptional people!

title: Fantastic GP surgery
body: I had to organise some time-sensitive blood tests for my newborn son, and the surgery were brilliant from start to finish. Covid has put enormous pressures on our NHS, and I expected to be told to wait but I was really pleased that didn’t happen! I found AskMyGP really helpful - I got a same-day reply asking me to come in the following day. I took my son into the surgery and it was a bit spooky, truth be told, with the waiting room sealed off and having to sit in my car until called up. But other than that the whole service was very professional. I got the blood results back about a week later, via email! Prior to covid this wouldn’t have happened, and I’m pleased that covid has pushed some of these sorts of interactions online. Previously I would have had to phone receptionists and ask if the bloods were in, then wait for the doctor to review them... so for me the whole virtual consultation thing is really convenient and much more efficient. The next month I had to take my other son in for his nasal flu thing, and again - could not fault this practice. Very efficient, in and out, brilliant nurses. Very well organised.

author: relative63
title: It's different being on the other side
body:
I was admitted as an emergency patient via A& E after experiencing abdominal pain.  
From the staff in the Emergency Department to the staff in ward 20- everyone was so nice and helpful. Miss Gray was also very good at keeping me updated on my plan. I wasn’t able to have my operation done due to the surgical team being busy with emergencies- but did have it done 2 days after being discharged.  
I would also like to give a massive thank you to the theatre staff. Being a healthcare professional is one thing, but it’s completely different being on the other side. They took the time to calm my nerves and give me a lot of reassurance whilst waiting to go in to theatre.  
Proud to be part of the NHS.

author: Tangerinetwirly
title: Trigeminal Neuralgia
body:
I was suffering with Trigeminal Neuralgia, an extremely painful condition. After having spent a week in a lot of pain not knowing what was wrong with me I had a horrific weekend. At one point I spent 4hours locked in my bathroom to shield my children from seeing me in so much agony. I got an emergency appointment with my GP and he was amazing. He listened to me, immediately diagnosed what was wrong and talked me through a plan of action. Being sure to tell me not to panic if the first treatment didn't work as there were other options. He started me on carbamazepine and arranged to phone me a few days later to see how I was and discuss my dose. He continued to either phone me or see me every few days to see how my symptoms were and to up the dose of medication. I was completely pain free within 14 days. I was then able to come off the medication after two months, confident that I can restart meds immediately the condition flares up again.  
I cannot thank my Dr enough. His treatment was exemplary and the hope & support he gave me that I would be pain free made a massive difference. I am in a Facebook group for Trigeminal Neuralgia sufferers and I know that many people do not experience such wonderful care from their GP's. I count myself very lucky that I happened to see this Dr that day

title: Doctors are Wonderful, Reception and intake staff…
body: Over the past 5 years of being a patient at the Vale practice I've never felt lacking in the high quality of care provided by the doctors at the practice. Through various health concerns I've had doctors and nurses checking on me, following up quickly with questions, and being generally very available, thoughtful and kind. This positive experience is heightend by the rude, unprofessional, and unhelpful manner of the reception staff particularly on the phone. I find myself interrupted, and not listened to on frequent occasions. I've found especially in the last two years a degree of sensitivity around my and my partners health to be entirely absent from the reception staff. This is very strange to me, as those answering the phones are tasked with speaking to people who, like I have been, potententially worried or in crisis. It doesn't take much effort to let someone finish a sentence, or to make them feel heard. This has been a continual frustration with the practice, and the only reason either my partner or myself continue to go there is that the doctors and nurses are so good. We regularly spend 15 minutes preparing to deal with the reception staff before calling, which creates a lot anxiety around a already heightened situation.

title: WORST PRACTICE IN BIRMINGHAM
body: I have been registered at this surgery for about 10 years and do not really use the surgery but everytime I have needed to call: always engaged. The staff are trained to appease and not assist. I self treat most of the time and only ever contact the GP in a real urgent situation. Poor admin process, always engaged never can get through to book appointment. Pat response call back tomorrow at 8am!  Useless. Their webite is made for Einstein to frustrate people and annoy patients, cannot access and find information on the website. Poor service from GPs who are invariably locums covering the day. If I could find better pratice I would leave. Have previously complained: no improvement. Not happy at all. If I had their business model I would be redundant. NHS is paying for a service which is unfit for purpose! But they get away with it as the public purse funds their salaries. Practice needs an intervention by CQC to improve standards. Would not recommend surgery. Awful.

title: Very efficient -- but no alcohol swab for vaccine…
body:
The process of vaccinating for covid is remarkably efficient.  The flow of patients is effortlessly maintained and all the staff are cheerful and polite.
I was very surprised however that for my second Pfizer jab today, the injection site was not swabbed with alcohol first -- the needle was just stuck in, taking with it into my arm whatever microbes were present on the skin.  I believe this is not correct practice.
Other than that, I have the highest opinion of this center.

author: magpietw47
title: Vaccine Clinic
body:
Really amazing.
I had a reaction to the vaccine which made me very worried about having the second one. However, the staff were so professional and gave me antihistamine to mitigate risk and observed me closely for over and hour afterwards. Even gave me chocolate!
The NHS is very hard to work in at times, but being on the receiving end of care is always so wonderful.
Thank you Helen, Sarah and Maddy

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: CCorr
title: Exceptional standard of care
body:
I attended the Day Procedure Unit in South Tyrone Hospital for an 8 weekly infusion. The staff here always look after me really well and put me at ease.  
The standard of care is exceptional and I cannot speak highly enough of the staff. Well done and a big thank you to all.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scorpiusbz73
title: My dad is 88 and alone in hospital
body:
My da is 88 so no smart phone or any phone for that matter. So contacting him while he is in hospital is not an option.  
With not being able to visit I felt cut off from him and was worrying about him as he is not as good at remembering or communicating.  
The virtual visit was great it put my mind at ease and I was relieved to see him.  
So thank you very much to the team who are providing this service

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mothernature44
title: Lengthy amount of time to try to get an appointment
body:
This is the 3rd week I have been trying to get an appointment with my GP. I have called on 5 different days, waited over half an hour on the phone each time, ranging from being no 50 in the queue to no 43 each time and eventually after getting through the 'Care Navigator' tells me there are no appointments left and to call back again tomorrow.  
My symptoms remain as severe pack pain, abdomen pain, arm weakness, memory loss, crashing tiredness, leg pain, pins and needles, shoulder pain, neck and jaw pain and for the past couple of days now dark coloured urine also. I also had issues with swallowing that I've had in the past and thankfully a nurse practitioner arranged blood tests and a referral to Hairmyres for this. She said I really needed to see a doctor for all of the other issues, as did the consultant I then saw at Hairmyres. How can I see a doctor when each time I call I am told all of the appointments are gone. Why can't an appointment then be made for the next day since it's obvious I need an appointment.  
Each phone call, the Care Navigator is told all of my symptoms. On one of the calls last week I was told if it was any consolation it sounded like what they had last October and it was so bad they had to set an alarm to remember to let my dog out. But there was still no appointments available today and that I needed to call back tomorrow. This is not acceptable behaviour. I'm clearly worried about my health and do not feel well one bit that's why I'm trying to get a doctor's appointment. It seems next to impossible.  
The whole process is inhumane and devoid of any compassion towards people trying to 'win the lottery' of getting an appointment. In my opinion it's awful and leaves me feeling very low and demoralised. I now have to wait in pain to go through the same process again tomorrow.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: IanH
title: An Ultrasound Scan at Western General hospital Edinburgh
body:
I was extremely anxious in regard to this (my second scan) as I was fearing the worst.  
The consultant was so good, professional and managed to put me at ease talking about TV programmes etc etc. It’s not often I write in about services but this lady was exceptional.... especially given how overworked they all are at the moment. In fact when I was there today, I was told she was alternating between two scan room.  
So grateful to her and all the staff. Incredibly nice.

author: Endymion
title: Painful biopsy
body:
Today I went to Darent Valley Hospital in Kent, referred by GP under the 2 week referral period as I had had vaginal bleeding. I was examined internally by a Senior Registrar who was very thorough but gentle and I didn’t experience any pain, only slight discomfort when a scope was inserted. The Registrar needed confirmation after a very thorough examination, and the Consultant was asked to come.  
I felt immediately when they appeared that they were perhaps under pressure and annoyed at having to attend. Their manner was very abrupt. They told me that they would have to do a biopsy and take a small amount of tissue from the cervix. They told me that it would be a little painful but would not last for long. I was not asked to sign a form to give permission for this procedure. I was not offered pain relief of any kind. The experience of the removal of tissue from such a sensitive internal area was no less than agony. I screamed during the biopsy, I have never felt pain like it although I have given birth twice, the pain was worse than that. My scream sounded unearthly to me, like an animal in terrible pain. Part of my inside was being cut without any anaesthetic.  
I am 73 years old. I was not told how to take care, I. e. not to lift things etc afterwards. I found that out from a web site. I haven’t cried for years, but I cried when waiting for my husband to collect me from the hospital. The consultant in my view showed no duty of care in the way they treated me, no consideration in failing to offer a local anaesthetic. I felt I had endured an assault.

readBy.name: University of Stirling, Faculty of Social Sciences

author: hydraks43
title: Great Care, Great caring Staff
body: My young son fell and broke his arm. We attended Hairmyres Hospital and the Doctors and Nurses went above and beyond to ensure that my Son was comfortable and well taken care of. From Doctor Alyssa, to the nurses, porters and reception staff everyone was very helpful.

author: Tomasz
title: Duty of care from GP
body:
I am highly appalled, intimidated and disappointed by the - otherwise a very short - telephone consultation with my experienced general practitioner. (duration 8 minutes).  
  
I would like to mention that in January, after consulting a psychiatrist from Mersey Care, I was ordered medical tests - blood, ECG of the heart. The issue concerned the possibility of increasing the received medications, including pain medication. The medications and doses prescribed for me had not been altered for at least three years. Despite the unsuccessful reconstructive procedure of the left foot, a lack of fusion for 16 months - living in severe pain - the GP did not consider increasing the doses of pain medication.  
  
The 8-minute telephone conversation I have mentioned shows that there is no such possibility for me as a patient. This is what the GP said. Therefore, a question that remains open for me is the sense of examinations being performed. In addition, the GP stated that the medications I receive are the maximum doses, which is not true. The conversation was characterized by the extraordinary haste and a lack of any interest, not even with the result of the hospital visit a few days prior. The GP made their decision without knowing anything about my mental and physical condition - and they had never seen me, nor had they seen any deformities in both feet and ankles - which is, in fact, the case with all doctors at Woolton House. This is not how a relationship between the patient and the GP is described in the NHS Constitution.  
  
My additional question concerning the Covid 19 immunization was met with a response that I am not considered a person with long-term illnesses, including severe disabilities, and that I am not currently eligible for vaccination - according to the government schedule, people with conditions like myself are now vaccinated. Unfortunately, I do not qualify... for what reasons? Or am I the incorrect nationality?  
  
To summarize. Having a high degree of respect towards doctors and being a man of culture, I clearly will not receive the help and support of NHS England, as representative of the overall healthcare system. The 8 minute consultation brought me to the brink of my emotional endurance. I am not garbage, nor a second-class human being. I do not consent to being treated beneath any standards. To the arrogant and downright rude behaviour of a physician as experienced as this one.  
In this regard, I do not see any further point of tormenting me with tests, because - as the GP stated - I will not receive an increased dose of painkillers (on the principle - 'because I say so').  
I also do not see the purpose and sense of a psychiatric consultation in April, because the declarations of a psychiatrist consultant do not translate into mundane reality. In my dealings with the GP.

author: October2020
title: Giving birth
body:
I feel that I had quite a traumatic experience during the birth of my son in October 2020.  
I admitted to The Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh one day mid October to be induced (as it was suspected that my baby was going to be rather large). The induction process took 3 days and while not exactly pleasant, was ok. The nurses were attentive and friendly and I was excited at the thought of giving birth and meeting my baby.  
On the 4th day at 3am I was transferred to the labour ward. I was met by an amazing midwife and student midwife. They put me at ease instantly and I was feeling relaxed. They broke my waters at 4am and started the oxytocin drip. I was then in the room for 6 hours before I had an unplanned c section. These 6 hours felt very traumatic for a number of reasons:  
1. The midwives shift finished and the brilliant team went home. I felt the new midwives didn’t really seem to care about me, they seemed more concerned with ticking boxes and paperwork.  
2. The baby was in the wrong position so the midwives were trying to coax him into a different position by moving me into very strange positions, despite it being not what I wanted or comfortable. I could feel myself getting distressed.  
3. I hadn’t dilated more than 3cm so the midwives rapidly increased the oxytocin drip until it reached its maximum levels. I had high blood pressure at this point and the contractions were medically distressing both me and the baby.  
4. The midwives spoke to a consultant and got authorisation to go above the maximum drip levels. The pain was too severe so I had pain relief in addition to gas and air.  
5. At this point I was told that the baby’s head was still in the wrong position. A c-section was mentioned. I couldn’t speak from the pain of the effect of the increased drip and the drugs. I relied on my husband to communicate my wishes. My husband, who had been virtually pushed aside during the process.  
I was then transferred to the theatre and the most amazing anaesthetist in the world (newly arrived from Italy, wearing a brilliant Star Wars head cover - I’m ashamed to say I’ve forgotten his name) quickly and efficiently administered the epidural and although I could barely communicate with him, his care and compassion meant the world to me.  
The operating theatre staff were all amazing. My son was delivered quickly and efficiently. The midwives took my husband so he could watch the weighing and checks etc. They were rude and abrupt with him and he wasn’t sure what was going on. They told him measurements without explaining what that meant - if everything was fine/normal or not? He remembers they put a white wool hat on my son’s head, then cut the umbilical cord so blood splattered all over the hat. Seems a strange thing to write about here, but that was his lasting memory. Not a good one.  
When we went to recovery, another very checklist oriented staff member tried to force me to breastfeed. Not showing me how to do it, but rather aggressively forcing my son to my breast. I did want to breastfeed and still am doing so thankfully, but it was not done in a supportive or helpful way post surgery. I was left feeling useless and confused about feeding.  
When I returned to the ward, my catheter broke and I was lying in urine for a while. I managed to get a nurse to help me but it was around shift change and I remember feeling that I was being a nuisance to her.  
Following this, I was on the ward until Sunday. When I tried to get nurses to help me with the baby or my c section recovery, it was a struggle. Sometimes it would take 40 mins to an hour for anyone to respond to the call button. Obviously if I needed to pick up, feed or change my son, this wasn’t helpful. I ended up doing everything myself. I feel like I was ignored because I refused the pain relief drugs (I have had bad experiences with post surgery morphine before and didn’t want to take it). A friend of mine was also on the ward at the same time, she always had support, had help with lifting the baby and the midwives took the baby for her at night so she could get some rest. I got none of these things.  
I had a breakdown on the Saturday night. I’d had virtually no sleep since the Monday when I was admitted for induction. The ward was loud with many disruptions overnight - moving bed spaces and crying babies. One nurse on shift was very helpful and arranged for me and my son to sit in a separate room at 3am to prevent us from leaving the hospital.  
On the Sunday, I asked to be discharged. When the consultant finally came to see me they got me mixed up with someone else and tried to go through someone else’s details, experiences and situation - at first they didn’t believe me when I told them their mistake. They then discharged me without going over any of the details of what had happened to me. I think I was in a bit of shock at this point and just desperate to leave.  
My baby was excessively crying at the same time and I remember no one helping me. I felt abandoned. A feeling that had characterised my stay in hospital post-birth.  
It’s taken me a while to really process my experience. I believe my labour was unnecessarily traumatic, as was my time post-birth in hospital.  
I am eternally grateful for the theatre staff and anaesthetist for both psychologically saving me and for bringing my baby into the world.

author: Appleface
title: Treatment for eye problems at the Glaucoma Clinic
body:
My right eye seemed to have made an excellent and rapid recovery after being damaged in accident in the 1970's. although it has needed several surgical interventions to keep it working effectively in the years up to my retirement in 2013.  
Then, however, functioning in it deteriorated significantly and in spite of a marvellous Corneal Graft operation in the RVH Ophthalmology Dept.in December 2016, a all sight in my right eye had failed by Easter 2018. About retirement time as well, a cataract had been noted in my left eye. It was developing only very slowly, but by summer 2018 I was unable to see to drive my car, read a book or newspaper, or watch television; so quite a miserable time for a widower living on his own!  
At that time I was referred to the Glaucoma Clinic Shankhill Rd. for a review of my condition, primarily the long term maintenance of my blind eye,  
During the review meeting the Consultant, having examined my eyes, gave me the bad news and the good news. Firstly on my blind right eye: that nothing could be done to recover sight in it but I would need to maintain it correctly, potting drops in it as prescribed and seeking help promptly if there seemed to be any change in its condition. Secondly on my left eye the good news was that it was generally in good condition and the cataract in it was definitely mature enough to be removed safely and that the Consultant would be happy to do the operation, scheduling it as a priority in the Clinic's work list.  
I was delighted to be able to look forward to a New Year when I could drive again, read, watch television and begin to redevelop a social life.  
The Clinic was as good as its word: they conducted the operation in January, they were clearly well experienced and everything went very smoothly, they had me in and out of the theatre in around half an hour, sitting up, looking around seeing things with a clarity I hadn't enjoyed for years.  
Apart from protecting the eye when sleeping for a few days and taking some additional antibiotic eye drops for a few weeks there were no additional precautions to be taken  
and bi-annual visits would suffice.  
March 2021  
At Christmas Time 2020 I began to be increasingly distracted by an irritation in the right-hand corner of my right eye. I remembered that Mr Frazer had mentioned that a suture had been intentionally left in that eye at the time the corneal graft was carried out (Jan. 17) and it might be might advisable to have it taken out at some time. Left it for a while because of Covid restrictions but decided to get advice from Glaucoma Clinic. Phoned Ms Knox's Sec. and explained my problem. She phoned back with an appointment date one week hence (in spite of Covid restrictions.)  
9th March Visited Glaucoma Clinic. Good Covid precautions in place. Seen by Nurse and by Doctor who gave me eye pressure test & Visual Field test. (O.K.). Met Consultant who discussed my eyes generally and my problem with my right eye. He geared up, sanitised and removed offending suture on the spot and gave me and gave me a prescription for chloramphenicol to apply in my eye for a fortnight. I told the Consultant how much I appreciated the helpfulness of the whole Clinic and he invited me to record that via Care Opinion. I have now used up the chloramphenicol and am having no problem with my eye so I am now trying to complete my part of the deal.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Tw1990
title: Change is very challenging
body:
I have recently been told by my health visitor that she will be moved to a different area from the end of April and I will have a new health visitor.  
I currently stay within rigside where I have recently moved to. since having my baby I have had issues with my mental health.  
I feel my health visitor has been a massive part in my journey to regain positive mental health again and this journey has only just begun.  
Faced with the fact she will no longer be working in rigside has caused me and can only imagine every other family she works with a great deal of uncertainty.  
Being in my current situation the thought of change is very challenging. Building a trusting relationship with anyone is a very hard thing to do and requires a lot of time and effort and for all of this to be taking away just like that is causing me a great deal of stress.  
I feel health visitors are a key part in family's with young children and should not be swapped about without really good cause as so many families depend on this service and don't cope with change very well.  
I for one am very disappointed to be losing my health visitor and feel this will have a massive impact on my current situation.

author: Aries 69
title: Excellent treatment received
body:
I was admitted to the Ambulant ward first, having suffered a stroke and series of mini strokes at home. I spent overnight in the short stay ward , every single member of staff who looked after me were amazing and never stopped.  
I was readmitted to A and E a few days later again staff were fantastic kind nurse who gave me tea and sandwich . The very hard working A&E Doctors and nurses were busy but the care given was excellent.  
My last experience was Emergency Care Ward again very busy but care was same as A&E. Doctors, nursing staff, staff serving meals, cleaning the wards, porters, XRay, Physiotherapist, I hope I haven't missed anyone.  
Just remember you all do an amazing job in difficult circumstances so a very big THANK YOU To all of you. Stay safe. 🙃😁.

author: Caitlin2
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: They have brought me on a long way
body: The services here are great however, after doing very little all weekend everybody came in at once on Monday morning and had me doing different things all day.   I wasn’t able to do anything this morning as I was too tired from yesterday. I feel that things should be paced out a bit better so that patients aren’t exhausted from the day before. Everything else is great: the room, the food, the physios, the OTs and the nurses - they can’t do enough for me. They have brought me on a long way from when I came in here.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scorpiuskz38
title: Such a relief
body: My mother is elderly. She has been in hospital ten days. I Havnt been able to talk to her as she cannot use a mobile phone or tablet/ laptop. Staff are too busy to phone me let alone make calls for her on the ward mobile phone.. Such a relief to have someone enable me to talk to her. And it helped her too. The enabler was so kind too.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: sculptorgd96
title: Childrens health visitors
body: I have had at least 6 different health visitors in the 4 years I've been seeing them. I have a 3 children under 5. one of my children didn't get any of his assessments on time because the health visitors kept changing and no one came to see me. Then when I had my third baby I finally got a health visitor I loved, she really cared, she was approachable and she had all assessments done on time. She is now being moved to a different area and I am devastated, every time I get a new health visitor I have to go through my story from the start again. I'm sure it is possible to keep her in this area if she wanted to stay, I know me and some of the others in the village I live in are all absolutely heartbroken about this. We have been through so many different health visitors and this one is reliable and lovely but here we are getting a new one again! Don't get me wrong the health visiting team is great and they've always helped if I've needed anything but the village is sick of changing all the time, these people are supposed to be there to build a relationship with and build trust with but we aren't getting the chance to do that because they're changing so much. We all built a relationship with her and we all love her, we are devastated she is being relocated.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Cd1
title: Phone first
body:
I used call first last Wednesday when I was very concerned about my toddler. The gentle man who answered the phone was very reassuring and helpful and assured me someone would call back within 20 minutes. A dr Sloan phoned promptly and was very helpful and asked lots of questions about my son and then arranged for him to be seen directly in paws ward. And later admitted This service allowed us to be seen promptly by the appropriate team  
Thank you

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: earthfm37
title: Excellent services from a fab team
body:
Came in through A&E recently. Service in A&E was very good, triaged quickly and as it was not as busy as usual went through A&E quickly. Felt I was extremely well looked after in a busy environment!  
Moved to Ward 9 - what a team!! All I can say is treatment and staff were first class. I was kept informed throughout of what was happening and going to happen to me. I had numerous bloods, CT Brain Scan, Lumbar puncture and a CT Angiogram of brain, all services received were excellent. Nursing staff were lovely, Drs thorough - in fact all staff carried out their jobs professionally from staff doing tea trolley/cleaning to pharmacist. Words cannot express my appreciation for the care I have received and follow up planned. Referred onto service - MRI & physio in order to see if possible, injection can help my diagnosed condition. Excellent services from a fab team in very trying times.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: travellertc66
title: Receiving my first jab
body:
I went for my first Pfizer jab often booking it online for the 60-64 age group. As soon as I arrived at the Ulster Hospital, I was greeted by a friendly volunteer, pointing out the hand sanitiser to me.  
As I proceeded through the extremely well organised procedure, a friendly lady confirmed my details, followed by a pleasant nurse administering the vaccination. I was impressed by being encouraged to sit in a waiting room for 15 minutes, which the nurse timed, before asking if I was OK and letting me go to the Admin table to book my second jab in May. All in all, a very positive experience!!  
Thank you, EVERYONE, in the NHS - you are doing a totally fantastic job, which is really appreciated, provided to us, for free, in great facilities! It was great receiving my first jab, and I would recommend this to everyone. Headed up so well by Dr McBride and Mr Swann!!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Cauldies
title: My second endoscopy in two weeks
body:
I have just had my second endoscopy in two weeks at the Victoria Hospital.  
My whole experience was excellent. The staff were well organised and very caring, with a great feeling of teamwork and patient reassurance throughout.  
All the steps in the process were clearly explained and my few questions answered.  
A great example of how to put patients at ease during an anxious time!  
My only issue was over the perennial problem of car parking at 5he Hospital.

author: deploymentsq43
title: Receiving covid vaccine
body: I received my first dose of the Covid vaccine today at Craigavon Leisure centre. The process was very smooth and well organised and the staff were extremely friendly, making the process really easy and comfortable.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: delphinuswc99
title: Second C-section
body:
I can’t speak highly enough of my amazing midwife that accompanied me to my recent C-Section. Daria, you are an consummate professional and just the loveliest woman.  
I was admitted to hospital after having had a difficult end to my pregnancy and it was decided I would have my C-Section. Daria came into the room and on first meeting she was just a breath of fresh air. Obviously very skilled at what she does but friendly, positive and instantly put myself and my husband at ease. Having had 2 other complex pregnancies and births this was exactly what was needed.  
The entire experience of giving birth to my third child was way beyond what I could have imagined and in fact quite life changing. Having had those difficult pregnancies and births before I was obviously scared. Daria and the entire team made the birth of my first son an experience we will never forget and I hope this message reaches Daria specifically to confirm how much she is appreciated.

author: mhexperience02
title: Assessment at the Stonebridge Centre
body:
I had my first assessment today (30/03/21) at the Stonebridge Centre with the LMHT. My assessment was with Kenni (CPN), and we had a student sitting in as well. The assessment went well and I felt I was listened to, but my main reason for coming on here is with the hopes that the student (I didn’t catch her name) can be given the recognition and praise she deserves. She listened patiently whilst I told my story, asked thought-provoking questions in a sensitive and compassionate manner and went out of her way to be inclusive in the way in which she spoke to me and asked questions (as she didn’t know my history before). I was so impressed with the way she interacted (even non verbally through body language) and added to the conversation (not just sat passively observing). I just wanted to leave this comment in the hopes that it can be forwarded to her placement supervisor or equivalent.  
To give some details to try and help identify the student - my appointment was at 13:00.  
I hope she can get the recognition she deserves.

author: VickyA
title: COVID 19 vaccination
body:
My husband and I were invited to get our first dose of vaccination against COVID 19 from the centre at the P& J Live venue. I really appreciated that we had the same appointment time, and that we had the option to go through the whole process together once we arrived. There was a reassuringly slick system in place, with plenty of sanitiser, well marked physical distancing arrangements and easy to follow signage.  
Most impressive was that every single one of the staff members whom we met, from the entrance to the venue right through to our exit again were welcoming, reassuring and clearly oriented to do an important job well. There were kind and smiling eyes above every mask, and while they kept people moving efficiently through the various steps of the process, the team also exuded a human warmth in their communication. However many times they had had to go through the same information and instructions before they got to us, there was no sense of any impatience or rush.  
The good humour that accompanied the highly organised work was very impressive (especially the mini dance around cleaning the rest chairs as soon as someone left! ). I'm not the bravest about injections, but was able to keep very relaxed through this. Congratulations and thank you for some great teamwork to all those involved.

author: castorpr85
title: Vaccination Clinic
body:
Wasn't asked if I needed a seat, not only the elderly that need assistance.  
Someone rushed me and told me to fill out the back of the consent form which was incorrect. A patient isn't a number, they are a person. Sometimes the task needs to be quick but not at the expense of the patient.  
Vaccination team excellent! !  
Thank you everyone.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: caringkk39
title: The clinical set up and team have been amazing
body: I've been receiving treatment in South Tyrone Clinical Day Centre for 4 months now. My treatment is biologic infusions for Ulcerative Colitis. The clinical set up and team in South Tyrone have been amazing. I'm new to these treatments and was very nervous commencing an immune system lowering regime at the height of the pandemic. The Day Centre has ample space for safe social distancing, toilets within easy reach, is spacious and airy. The setting feels less intimidating than arrival and treatment at the main hospital sites of CAH or DHH. The team - nurses, doctors, healthcare support staff, have been fabulous in settling my nerves, explaining my treatments, helping me feel safe, and doing everything they can to ensure my experience goes smoothly every time. I'd be very happy to come to South Tyrone on a regular and ongoing basis for these treatments. Thank you to the team who've been so knowledgeable and supportive in this great safe space.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: browserkb68
title: District nurses are great
body: I have had district nurses visiting since October to help me with dressings on a wound that is taking time to heal. There are about 4 or 5 different nurses that I see and they have all been so wonderful and kind.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: SP4
title: Help At Home.
body:
The team have been really helpful from initial contact.
They assessed the needs required and put an action plan in place.
All carried out efficiently.

author: Anon patient
title: Trying to get through by phone
body: I know that it can be busy but I have been trying to phone for two days now and all I get is user busy and never get to speak to anyone over 200 calls now and still no joy.

readBy.name: Meadowgreen Health Centre & The Avenue Medical Practice

author: pegasusqw73
title: COVID vaccination
body: I got my vaccination yesterday in Dundee in the Caird Hall. It couldn't have been better - really well organised without feeling cold or procedural, from hand sanitising and everyone being asked to use a fresh disposable mask to ushers to the right station. The nurse or doctor was really nice and calm, she talked me through everything, and I had the feeling that I got lots of time (though it was less than 10mins in total), it was all really reassuring and neither having to wait nor feeling pushed through too quickly.

author: JDT
title: On complex medications with drug sensitivity
body:
In patient. Not Covid but had been shielding. Complex health record. On complex medications with many drug sensitivity.  
Poor communication from staff. In a side room. Staff did not discuss care or treatment as in consent. Once given antibiotics that the organism I ws infected with were resistant too. These were prescribed without any discussion with me. Next prescribed antibiotics that I was already sensitive to - again prescribed without discussion with me. In fact the type of antibiotics ordered by the consultant would be acceptable but these were not then by ones given.  
I have poor venous access. Treated like a living pincushion to multiple multiple failed attempts to cannulate. Leaving me with infected untreated severe cellulitis of my right hand. Staff not helpful. Consultant ordered a long line. Not done the day ordered so was left 3 days with no results of renal function etc. Dehydrated- not rescued or corrected. Told by staff to eat. Despite no appetite and nauseated. Treated with little respect not using my name but called ‘love’ ‘their love’ may be nice from my partner, not from a stranger.

author: severityjz36
title: COVID 19 2nd vaccination
body: Very smooth setup for queuing and registering before the injection. Well spoken and informative nurse performing the injection. Thank you.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Brilliant experience
body: My mum who has osteoporosis has more than likely fractured a bone.  I called this morning and yes it was engaged for a while but lines had just opened so it was to be expected.  Receptionist was pleasant, polite and knowledgeable, told me a GP would call mum for a consultation and literally an hour later mum was called and booked in for a scan today.   Well done all involved in mums care !  I am an NHS worker myself and know the pressure you are under and this was top treatment today.

title: I just don't get it!
body: This is more about my 66yr old mum than me, her 32yr old son, but this practise just doesn't seem to function well. Appointments take forever, fair enough, but when you don't get one and you're seen, it's another battle trying to follow up regarding your situation. You would expect that if you've been seen, they would book your follow up on the spot, and if any tests need doing, you would at least get a text sms when they are all completed to put your mind at ease. But most times they forget about you. And then when you try to follow up, they tell you to call back on a specific day, and when you do that the doctor that was supposed to do the follow up is not available and you have to deal with another doctor who is unfamiliar with you and the situation. I wish there was a private clinic near by because this setup seems higgledy-piggledy and the follow up function is dire. I'd prefer to pay out of pocket, at least for my mum, as that's what she does in the Caribbean where she's from and gets seen and tests done one the day! Back there might not have as many specialists as the UK, but the GP side of things is so much simpler and quicker. Are there any private clinics near Saffron Walden?

author: aquilanj57
title: Hospital visit
body:
Visited R.A.H for gestational diabetes test in March.  
Was made to feel very welcome in a nice calm and relaxed atmosphere

author: whiskeyqj83
title: Diabetes testing whilst pregnant
body: Taken right away and made to feel comfortable and at ease from the get go. Happen to have been in with a friend so it helped make my waiting time easier. All covid guidelines were followed and felt safe.

author: requirementpm83
title: Covid 19 test
body: I arrived at the woodside testing facility, was spkoe to promptly in my car, the next few processes where explained to me in a clear and consise manner.   The whole process was well organised and timely.   I was made feel at ease during the test, the nurse explained the importance of obtaining a good sample, unpleasant as the nasal one is (for me at least - narrow nasal passages) I was no worse or in any significant discomfort from having the test.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: libratd67
title: Such attention to detail
body:
Attended Cardiology Hub in March.  
Emergency appointment arranged for me with prompt pleasant & helpful input from Michelle and Andrew.  
Nothing was too much trouble.  
Dr Hughes attended and organised investigation & treatment plan with full explanation.  
So planned with outcome, Such attention to detail and attitude outstanding  
Almost make you want to be ill - *almost* 😊

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: FAM1992
title: Surgical Skin Team
body: I can't thank David & Lee Ann enough for the support I received today when I went in for a mole removal, they were both absolutely brilliant, they spoke all the way through and kept my mind off of what was happening. Great assets to the team, they should be proud of themselves!

author: decembersw55
title: Help with Anorexia
body: It was very scary at first the thought of moving away from home and it felt like everyone was against me, But I soon released everyone wanted the best for me and to help me. Something that would of took me years in the community has taken me a few months at Pegasus and I am so thankful for the help I recieved during me stay. I feel I progressed in many ways since my admission but I know the battle isn’t over yet and this is only a part of my recovery journey. I would not be where I am today without Pegasus!

author: pluscc36
title: Gallbladder removal surgery
body:
From the start of my admittance in the pre-assessment unit I was very happy with my treatment. In the SEAL unit on the day of my admittance I was kept well informed of the procedure and how things would happen. I was was made to feel at ease. Even the walk to theatre wasn't as daunting as I thought it would be as the nurse chatted away all the time.  
When I woke up I was in ward 52. The nurses here were excellent.. I had a bit of a bad time during the night as my wounds started bleeding. They re-dressed them 2-3 times and in the morning the surgeon came and put removeable stitches in and glue. I also must thank the two nurses who made me feel at ease when I had to have a bed bath. I had fainted and was sick in the morning so not able to get out of bed for a wee while. I never thought I would have the indignity of a bed bath but they were so good about it.  
The nurses also took the time to keep my husband informed of all that was happening which was very important in these - no visiting times. All in all - although I was in a bit longer than expected I have nothing but praise for the surgeon, anaesthetist, nurses and domestics.

author: papadq58
title: Never been prouder of our NHS
body:
I got the vaccination for covid. The service was quick, efficient. I felt safe and secure.  
Staff were super organised and managed everyone with a smile and were very professional.  
Never been prouder of our NHS during these times!!  
Thank you

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: earthpw69
title: Hospital Vaccine
body:
Personality of the staff was great - reassuring, confident, friendly  
relaxed, no hesitation, all questions were answered  
I can't fault anything as the staff were wonderful

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: muscacz83
title: Covid vaccine
body: So efficient. Friendly and approachable staff. Exceptionally organised and Covid safe. Thank you to you all.

author: Racieuto
title: Rapid treatment but long wait for information
body: I was admitted to acute medical 8. The nurse staff on the ward were run off their feet but also very helpful and tried to keep me informed. The communication from the doctor however was very poor to myself and it seemed also towards the nurses. I was very quickly given several tests and scans but the doctors were busy to discuss the results and I had to wait a long time for a letter and medication to go home. There were several patients whose behaviour was disgusting and personally I would have called the police but them nurses dealt with them firmly and professionally. I would particularly like to thank Ashley and Susan overnight and Karen Emma and Lauren whose dogged determination to get me and other patients home was very impressive

author: MumG
title: First class care from NIAS
body: Whilst we all hope not to need to use ambulance services, last night my daughter   required emergency attention. After sustaining a dislocation of her knee cap, my 11 year old daughter was both in significant pain and distressed. The ambulance (from Coleraine) arrived promptly and the staff in attendance, William and Noelle, were amazing. They were caring, attentive and had just the approach needed with a very frightened child. I couldn’t have asked for any more and am very grateful that my daughter’s first experience of such emergency care was one that inspired confidence in the expertise shown. First class care

author: Leo257
title: Emergency Surgery NHS Forth Valley
body:
I recently become unwell with abdominal pain and was sent to Forth Valley Royal Hospital for further investigations by my own gp.  
Following an ultrasound, I was diagnosed with a ruptured appendix and had surgery to remove it.  
I arrived at the hospital around lunch time and within a few quick hours, I had blood taken, a scan, pain killers, iv antibiotics and was prepared for surgery. I think this is pretty impressive given the pressures the hospital is currently under due to the Covid-19 pandemic.  
I would like to thank everyone involved in my care, from the housekeepers, domestic staff, theatre staff, nurses, doctors and consultants. Special thank yous to the nursing staff of ward B11 and B12.  
During my stay I developed a post- op temperature and as a precaution I had to be tested for Covid. Thankfully it was negative but, whilst waiting on results, I had to be kept in isolation and the staff had to wear full Ppe before coming in to my room. Everyone was very professional and kind. It must be scary for staff knowing that they are potentially being exposed to this virus, but no one treated me any differently and did their best to keep me calm.  
I was in hospital for six days and it was difficult as I couldn’t see my children or loved ones. The staff did their best to keep my spirits up and I’m very grateful for that too.

author: defenderdr97
title: Giving birth
body: I came in to the maternity unit at the BGH to be induced and then to deliver my daughter. I was nervous about the balloon induction, but the staff were really kind and supportive, allowing me to have gas and air and talking me through the process. It was comfortable and much less frightening than I thought. I was able to go home overnight before coming back to have my waters broken. Once labour started I was able to labour in my own, then get into the pool for as long as I warned. Staff were so kind, working around contractions to look after me, and only making themselves known when absolutely essential. When the pain became too much they quickly arranged for an epidural which was delivered professionally and kindly by the fantastic anaesthetist. Much more comfortable, I was able to enjoy labouring (the dose was just what I wanted-took away the worst of the pain but left function and some sensation). When it came time to push I was guided and supported by two lovely midwives who encouraged me and enabled me to labour in the position I wanted. I felt so in control of my choices and experiences throughout that the whole process was magical. Thank you to all the staff who helped us have such a wonderful day preparing to meet, and then delivering, our daughter.

author: GMcP
title: Labour and delivery of my first baby!
body:
I had my little girl in the Queen Elizabeth Univeristy Hospital in Glasgow in February and wanted to take the time to thank some of the staff who looked after me during my labour and delivery, as well as in the post natal ward.  
I arrived on the afternoon before and went to maternity assessment. The midwife who looked after me was fantastic! After examination I was told I was 3cm dilated and my husband could come and join me as I’d be moving to the labour ward shortly. The pain at this point was pretty intense already and the midwife was incredible at helping me manage my contractions and keeping me as calm as possible.  
When we arrived in the labour ward the next midwife initially looking after us wasn’t great. She was generally quite rude and dismissive and as I was really struggling with the pain at this point her attitude was quite disheartening. I was refused access to a birthing pool, told I would need to remain in bed for constant monitoring and that I wasn’t allowed to eat or drink anything other than water. Having done hypnobirthing I knew my rights and that eating and drinking shouldn’t have been denied. Although I had gestational diabetes, my consultant had advised I was incredibly healthy and there was no need for labour restrictions to be placed on me (such as no birthing pool/continuous monitoring). I found the pain difficult to manage as I wasn’t allowed to move from the bed so opted for gas and air, followed by an epidural to help me manage the pain. The staff members who administered my epidural were absolutely amazing and kept me calm and informed.  
When the shift staff changed to night shift I was joined by 2 wonderful midwifes. They were so kind, supportive and friendly. They told me what was happening each step of the way, why they were doing certain tests and checks and were very considerate of my feelings. With them in the room my husband and I instantly became more relaxed and actually enjoyed the process more.  
Following several hours with my epidural, a hormone drip to keep contractions going and having my waters broken, I was stuck at 8cm dilated and baby was beginning to get a little stressed...baby had also done a poop inside so there were concerns regarding this also. At this point a doctor came in to assess and advised they’d leave me for another few hours to progress, but a c section may be required. After a few more hours I was assessed again and it was decided surgery was the best option. I was initially a little upset with this, however the staff offered great comfort and reassurance. I met with the anaesthetist who was so lovely and explained all surgical procedures to me.  
Throughout my time in theatre everyone I have mentioned, along with so many more staff, were all on hand to offer words of encouragement and support to my husband and I. The c section went smoothly and before I knew it we were in recovery with our healthy baby girl!  
When I was moved to the postnatal ward (ward 50, I think!) my husband had to leave. I was pretty terrified at being alone with my new baby girl as I was still numb and unable to move my legs due to the anaesthetic I had been given. I needn’t have worried though as I was given outstanding care and support in the ward by the staff, specifically one person who offered help and encouragement with breastfeeding (I honestly don’t believe we’d have had a successful breastfeeding journey with her!) and provided moral support to me as I was quite nervous as a first time mum looking after a tiny baby!  
I cannot thank all the staff at QEUH enough for the care provided to me and my little one during this time. I honestly wish I could thank them all individually in person as they truly were amazing!

author: March21
title: Forever grateful to my midwives
body:
Now that I have given birth, I can't believe how under-appreciated midwives are.. they are the most special people with such an important, caring profession.  
I was so anxious about giving birth with the current situation and really had no idea what to expect, but there was no need to worry at all. I went to the out of hours triage department at Forth Valley where I was taken into a room with Katie (I think was her name, wish I knew for sure! ), and I think she was as surprised as me to find out how far along I was.  
She didn't leave my side once until our baby girl was safely in my arms - she was just so amazing at keeping me as calm as could be and talking to me the whole time - something about her voice just made me feel safe & in control.  
Special recognition has to go to Billie the student midwife who was also there delivering our baby, for telling me how to breath & especially letting me squeeze her hand so tight - you've got an amazing career ahead of you.  
Susan looked after me after I had given birth and the care & reassurance from her was exceptional. A lot of the work involved with being a midwife must be far from easy but she just seemed so happy and content with what she was doing, even at 3am.  
I'll be forever grateful to the 3 of them, and the rest of the Maternity Staff.

author: woodpigeonrf47
title: An excellent service
body:
I went to the minor surgical skin team at Forth Valley Royal Hospital for a biopsy. The Care was excellent, David, who was the attending nurse, was very knowledgeable and very professional.  
An excellent experience

author: graingeremz
title: My GP
body:
I work full time and it's hard to get appointments to suit me, my Gp gave me a phone appointment and then arranged for me to be seen face to face the next day and as one of their 1st clients of the day to ensure I did not need to miss any time at work.  
She understood that it's hard for some employers to offer short notice leave to attend appointments and went out of her way to call me back 2 times as I missed their calls due to my work and then they fit me in at a time that suited around work.  
I am so grateful for the effort and personalization of my appointment and the quality of care given to me by my GP. Also, the surgery staff is helpful and nothing is ever too much trouble.  
I feel lucky as I hear stories from others waiting weeks for appointments and being told they have little flexibility by their GPs.  
Thank you so much!!!!!

author: sigmatt87
title: Virtual visiting
body: It was such a pleasant experience. It was the first time I have seen my daughter since Christmas. Thank you Dominik.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: bonanzark44
title: They were there for me
body:
After been in a relationship, where he used alcohol as a controlling mechanism, I decided to take control and ask for help.  
STARS were there for me. Took me through the pamphlets step by step and ring every week to see how I am doing.

author: Johnnymac
title: Vaccination
body: The whole process was simple and ran like clock work. The staff were efficient and polite and friendly. This was at the leisure centre in Craigavon N. Ireland. My only little gripe would be to cut down on the leaflets. Most people wont read beyond the first paragraph. Who reads off a paper nowadays? Save on litter, expense and time. Send it to the equipment they are continually plugged into. A small business card with contact details on it to point them in the right direction of the relevant information would be sufficient. However thank you so much for the injection and all your hard work.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Hamimo
title: An amazing orthoptist
body:
I have been attending orthoptics with my daughter for a little while now after her preschool eye test flagging up some mild issues. We are often seen by an orthoptist called Julianne at Wishaw hospital in Lanarkshire.  
Julianne has the most amazing manner about her and is absolutely fantastic with my daughter. I'm not sure if Julianne is aware that my daughter is autistic or if she just has a natural way with children and being able to gauge their needs. But every time we attend I often want to say to someone how great she is.  
People are so quick to complain but no one really takes the time when someone has been doing something well to give them the credit. So thanks Julianne, credit where credit is due! You are an asset to the NHS!

author: Mrs AW
title: Care given by DECSA team
body: Fathers health deteriorated had chronic heart failure and kidneys were failing too. He didnt want to be admitted to hospital. GP referred him to team at RVH and very next day a care plan was devised and hospital bed delivery arranged. The lead nurse practitioner - Jane was excellent in keeping in touch with family and explaining everything she was putting in place. Thanks to Jane and the team he was able to spend his last days at home surrounded by family .

author: blackbirdpy78
title: Foyle Arena Vaccine Centre
body: Attended for vaccine number 2 in April, was administered by Dr. Murphy and another Male Dr who I didnt see his name badge. Both were friendly and made me feel so relaxed. Quick and professional service. Thank you

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Deeg1962
title: Alcohol, Controlled drinking, Improved wellbeing
body:
I feel that with the help of my key worker, Marc, who never judged me for my drinking behaviour, and I felt really believed in me, I have achieved my treatment goal with no problems. The non judgmental approach and staged treatment plan worked, and I must say I never believed it would, when I started treatment in October 2020. I was consuming in excess of 100 units of alcohol per week and I am now well within the government guidelines and implement drink free days too.  
I don't think about alcohol as playing a big role in my life anymore and feel in total control. my physical has also improved, my blood pressure has reduced, my liver function tests are now normal and my general wellbeing is the best it has been for as long as I can remember.

title: Great practice
body:
I went to receive a COVID jab at a venue organised by The Groves - a local church. The organisation was simply amazing! Loads of volunteers across the age spectrum were present to ensure that the process went smoothly. There were people to direct you where to go on arrival, take your temperature , provide hand sanitiser, check you in, point out where to have the jab...... care and attention which was both first rate and very reassuring. 
I had my jab bang on time and was then directed into a waiting area (the church itself) where people were required to stay for 15 minutes to ensure all was well. It was here that I encountered the piece de resistance in the shape of a pianist playing relaxing music for the benefit of all. So thoughtful!
Kudos to all at The Groves and all the volunteers.

author: circinushp73
title: Staff at Holsworthy.
body:
Lifesaver being able to come to Holsworthy. I enjoy going to Seamoor but the nurses were under so much pressure there was less time to sit and chat.
The staff at Holsworthy understand the level of need you have including ‘banter’ and have more time to respond to equipment signals, having had my first dose of medication reduced, Kim helped to manage my care and improve my medical condition. The offering of beverages and time they have makes the experience so much easier. I would be quite upset and disappointed if I were unable to get my treatment at either of the community hospitals.
The care I have received have given me such a better quality-of-life from the community team.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: braceyz47
title: Excellent treatment in ambulatory care at Forth Valley Hospital
body: I had a lesion removed from my back at Forth Valley hospital. From my consultation in the dermatology department with Dr Craig and the procedure in the ambulatory care unit, I received excellent care. I was extremely impressed by the standard of care which I received. The staff in the ambulatory care unit, David, who carried out the procedure so perfectly, Lee-Ann and Abby were all wonderful. They were so professional and caring. From the moment that David greeted me in the waiting room I felt l was in safe hands. He was so calm and reassuring.

author: Tayberry
title: End of life care, Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy
body: My mother was admitted to the Victoria Hospital in March and quickly diagnosed with an inoperable tumour. She was transferred to Ward 44 and remained there until her death. I would like to thank the staff of all levels who work on that ward for everything they did to keep my Mum comfortable during her last weeks. They were kind, compassionate, considerate and friendly. Always professional, despite often being short staffed and always very busy. Not only did they look after my Mum but they also treated me with such kindness throughout the long hours that I spent on the ward sitting by her bedside. I am very grateful to the wonderful staff on Ward 44.

author: June01
title: My Mother
body:
On 7th March 2021 my mother became very short of breath and was clearly unwell. We contacted the Out of Hours Doctor who came to the home to see Mum. My Mother was adamant she did not want to go into hospital as she had been in hospital for 5 weeks over Christmas and due to Covid she was not allowed visitors, which of course was an extremely difficult time for both her and her family.  
The Doctor said he would contact her GP and suggested the Acute Care Team should come to the home to see her. The Acute Care Team arrived to access Mum on the 8th March. What a relief it was for us to have this Medical Support as since Mum came home from hospital we had only received phone calls from her GP which was totally inadequate.  
We had an extremely professional Medical Army ascending on her home. They completely took over her care. We had Consultants, Doctors, Nurses, Dietitians, and Occupational Health etc. all working tirelessly in the home to stabilize her. They carried out tests and prescribed medications and continued to work with her for almost a week until her condition improved. The care she received from the Acute Care Team was second to none. We believe she would not have been given the same one to one care in hospital and of course she was able to remain in her home with her family around her.  
We as a family are always be grateful to the whole team and would highly recommend this brilliant service.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Oopsy daisy
title: DBT has been life changing for me
body:
I was diagnosed with EUPD (emotional unstable personality disorder) and got referred to the personality disorder service for dialectical behavioural therapy (DBT).  
The DBT has been absolutely life changing and has made such a massive difference to my life compared to previous attempts at other mental health services which didn't help me a lot.  
The DBT service is an absolutely amazing service and I would 100% recommend them.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: JoVenna
title: Ballycastle District Nurses
body: After my mother came home from Causeway Hospital where she received stunning care we had to have a home care package in place which was organised between the hospital and northern trust in partnership with Platinum home care services in Ballycastle and for the last seven months mammy had a team of angels giving her care daily alongside this was a regular brilliant professional team of district nurses under team leader McCambridge, when a call was made for advice or the need of any nursing support the house call was prompt and conducted in a kind homely caring way. many of the calls were given by the excellent nurse Duncan Mother was so beautifully looked after time after time and when she passed on a month ago there were a few sad ladies from these teams as they and mammy had built such a wonderful respite Ballycastle health care professionals pharmacist Michael, doctors Harrison and Chestnutt, receptionist, physio Janet, Occupational therapist Mary and district nurses and care team are the best professionals my mammy was blessed to know thank you.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: attendantzd47
title: Covid-19 vaccination
body: I attended the allergy clinic at Craigavon Hospital yesterday. The whole process was very well organised and I felt very safe. Many thanks to all the staff including Rebecca, who took my details when I arrived, Olivia, nurse in charge and Denise, my vaccinator. Everyone I met was very friendly and supportive and I have no fears about returning for my second vaccine. Keep up the good work!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: serpensjw59
title: Alcohol Dependence and Depression
body:
I was at my very lowest with alcoholism, consuming around 400 units per week, suffering horrendous bouts of depression and personality problems, I was on the verge of being homeless, incarcerated or possibly even hospitalisation to save my life, then I went to CGL,  
they assessed me and then my recovery journey began one of which would be my salvation in every walk of life including my sanity and life.  
I attended numerous groups of EBI, Smart and foundations and underwent detox both ambulatory and residential whilst continuing my therapy with CGL.  
I am now currently 250 days sober from my last residential detox admission and currently working on relapse prevention and recovery through foundations.  
I am forever grateful to CGL, and in particular Jack, Anthony, Veronica and Chandni, all of whom have supported me unconditionally to finally recover and embrace sobriety, save and change my life around, without their support I would have lost everything, now I am so happy and at peace with life and also again with the help of Chandni we are exploring my psychological issues to maintain my recovery and get further help from mental health services with secondary investigation.  
I will be forever indebted to CGL and sincerely hope they continue offering their support and services as they currently do with the same staff and facilitators as cgl because I feel any drastic changes to their support network and protocol could have a very negative and harmful effect on my recovery and mental health.  
CGL are so professional, polite, supportive and understanding with a fantastic variety of therapy, groups and activities, please may it continue as CHANGE, GROW, LIVE because I certainly have because of them.

author: Mummyof2andwife
title: Care and compassion at paediatric cardiology
body:
My daughter was diagnosed with pulmonary stenosis at a few weeks old. Dr Smith at the Hospital for Children was kind and compassionate at the time.  
We have just had our 1 year review, and he showed just the same care and compassion and reassurance. I really appreciated the support, especially when only one parent is allowed in, it can be very overwhelming.

author: Will66
title: BAU Contingency Surgical Skin Team were first class.
body: I had a suspect 'growth' removed from my arm by Kirsty and Aileen. The process was first class. I was not kept waiting too long. The staff were very friendly and put me at ease straight away. The procedure was done quickly, painlessly and effectively. I was kept fully informed throughout about every stage of the process, and was fully informed about after procedure care. It was clear that Kirsty and Aileen were totally concerned and fully committed to my well-being through the procedure.

author: ALBA5757
title: Examination and diagnosis
body: I registered my Father with my local GP practice recently, after him having a fall at his own home whilst living on his own. I can’t thank my surgery enough in which they examined and assessed his medical condition. They are an exemplary GP practice and I cannot express my gratitude to them enough in the way they in which they went about their work.

author: THaighton
title: My wife’s admission to BCH Cancer Centre
